steps: Carefully review all 25 pages of the handout for Part 01, focusing on the configuration steps for setting up RDS and S3 in AWS
Check for any discrepancies or significant differences between the screenshots in the handout and the current AWS interface
Seek clarification on any steps that are unclear or where you are unsure of what to do
Complete the AWS setup for Part 01 by following the configuration steps provided in the handout
Ensure that the server-side components (RDS and S3) are properly configured and functioning as intended before moving on to Part 02
Review the details provided in the handout for Part 02, which focus on client-side development with Python using the boto library
Build a Python client to interact with RDS and S3 as outlined in the handout for Part 02
Test the functionality of the Python client to ensure it can successfully interact with RDS and S3
Submit Parts 01 and 02 by the specified deadline of Wednesday April 10th, with the option for late submissions accepted until Friday April 12th
Read through the assignment description carefully to fully understand the requirements and expectations
Break down the assignment into manageable tasks and create a timeline for completion
Start by reviewing any relevant course material and notes to refresh your understanding of the concepts needed for the assignment
Work on each task systematically, ensuring each step is completed accurately before moving on to the next
Proofread and review your work to check for any errors or inconsistencies before submitting the assignment
Read and summarize Descartes' Fifth and Sixth Meditation
Examine Descartes' arguments on the distinction between mind and body
Analyze Descartes' reasoning behind the mind-body dualism
Study the Correspondence between Descartes and Elizabeth
Read Galileo's The Assayer and focus on the concept of Corpuscularianism
Compare and contrast Descartes' and Galileo's views on the mind-body relationship
Formulate a cohesive argument on how Descartes proves the distinction between mind and body
Carefully read the README file for assignment instructions
Submit assignment by 11:59 pm on April 10th (Wed.)
Make an additional submission by Fri Apr 12 at noon if needed, with credit loss
Follow the ratio for credit loss specified in the additional submission guidelines
Read and fully understand the text 'Ethics: Part i, Definitions, Axioms, Propositions 1-20 (i, 158-68) by Baruch Spinoza'
Identify key points and arguments made by Spinoza regarding the relationship between God and the rest of existence
Analyze how Spinoza defines and conceptualizes God within his philosophical framework
Examine how Spinoza's definitions, axioms, and propositions in the text provide insights into the nature of the relationship between God and the rest of existence
Evaluate and synthesize the information gathered to form a coherent understanding of Spinoza's perspective on God's relationship to the rest of existence
Review all material covered in class leading up to the exam
Practice writing essays or short responses by hand to prepare for the handwritten aspect of the exam
Create flashcards or study guides to help memorize key information
Get a good night's sleep and eat a healthy breakfast before the exam
Arrive early to the exam location to ensure you have enough time to mentally prepare
Form a team with a maximum of 3 members
Wait for more details on the final project to be published
Plan the project based on the additional information provided
Divide tasks among team members efficiently
Work collaboratively to complete the final project
Read Spinoza's Ethics: Part ii, Definitions, Axioms, Propositions 1-13, 35, 38-40 (i, 178-83, 192-5) thoroughly to understand his views on the relationship between mind and body.
Focus on Spinoza's arguments and explanations regarding the connection between mind and body in his work.
Analyze and interpret the specific references and examples provided by Spinoza to support his theory of the mind-body relationship.
Consider any objections or counterarguments that Spinoza addresses in relation to the mind-body problem.
Draw connections and comparisons between Spinoza's views on the mind-body relationship and other philosophical perspectives on the topic.
Formulate your own critical evaluation and interpretation of Spinoza's position on the relationship between mind and body, incorporating additional research and scholarly sources as needed.
Read Spinoza's Ethics: Part i, Propositions 21-36 and Appendix (i, 169-78)
Read V.F. Cordova's How It Is, specifically the chapter 'Usen: The Unidentifiable Is'
Analyze the arguments presented by Spinoza and Cordova regarding the question of whether God freely chooses to create the world
Consider any similarities or differences between the perspectives of Spinoza and Cordova
Formulate your own conclusion based on the readings and analysis conducted
Write a comprehensive response to the question 'Does God freely choose to create the world?' incorporating insights from Spinoza and Cordova
Read and understand the text 'Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, Discourse on Metaphysics: 1-17, 33–7 (i, 234-45, 254–7)'
Identify key passages that specifically address the notion of an individual substance
Analyze the arguments and explanations provided by Leibniz regarding individual substances
Summarize the definition and characteristics of an individual substance as presented in the text
Reflect on the implications and significance of the notion of an individual substance in metaphysics
Read Nicolas Malebranche's Search after Truth: iii.ii.6 (i, 220-2)
Analyze the concept of occasional causes and their relationship to real causes in the text
Identify key arguments and evidence presented by Malebranche on occasional causes
Evaluate whether occasional causes can be considered as real causes based on Malebranche's arguments
Formulate a personal interpretation and conclusion on the nature of occasional causes as real causes
Read Leibniz's 'The Principles of Philosophy, or, the Monadology' (pages 285-293)
Read Leibniz's Third & Fourth Letters to Clarke (pages 307-313)
Read the article by J.E.H. Smith on Leibniz and the Internet
Prepare notes on the key points and arguments in the readings
Draft an outline for a summary or analysis of the readings
Write a coherent and well-structured response to the readings
Proofread and revise the response for clarity and coherence
Submit the assignment on time
